poll_list.title: Ratification Poll for Facilitator Onboarding to IS-001 - @psychonaut (MIP41c4-SP34) - June 13, 2022

discourse_list.title: MIP41c4-SP34: Immunefi Security Core Unit Facilitator Onboarding - IS-001

content.content: MIP41c4-SP34: Immunefi Security Core Unit Facilitator Onboarding - IS-001  Preamble MIP41c4-SP#: 34 Author(s): @psychonaut Contributors: Tags: core-unit, cu-is-001, facilitator Status: Rejected Date Applied: 2022-04-13 Date Ratified: N/A Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip41c4-sp34-immunefi-security-core-unit-facilitator-onboarding-is-001/14610 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmaR6q4L   Sentence Summary Add @psychonaut (Jpritikin Industries, Inc) as a co-Facilitator for Core Unit IS-001: Immunefi Security.  Specification  Motivation I have worked as Deputy Facilitator for Immunefi Security since its inception on Dec 2021 and, during part of its incubation period under SES, two month prior (Oct and Nov 2021). I have taken charge of the accounting, wrote status updates, and contributed to our core unit’s goals. Our current Facilitator, @travinimmunefi, continues to lead with long-term strategic planning, but is stretched thin by his many other responsibilities. Often, when Travin has scheduling conflicts, I am asked to attend the weekly Mandated Actor’s meeting in his place. This MIP formalizes what is essentially already the status quo. This proposal is not about compensation. My compensation will actually go down by about 1000 DAI/month because I will no longer be eligible for SourceCred. The main motivation is to become vetted by MKR holders for the high-trust role mandated by our Core Unit.  Core Unit ID IS-001  Facilitator name and information  Forum: @psychonaut  Discord: psychonaut#7023 Email: [email protected] Telegram: @Psychonaut7023  Ethereum Address: 0xFfC87601A80d3e4F0aF083a899e3fee203C23cF0   Facilitator Commitment  Act as a representative of the CU in internal Maker community and external communications channels Co-manage the social media accounts of the CU Co-lead the public calls hosted by the CU, including, but not limited to, office hours and those open to the Maker ecosystem Be a primary point of contact (non-technical) for other CUs Take lead on collaborations with other CUs  Example: Emergency PlayBook (w/ GovComms)   Create initiatives for the CU to provide a better service to the Maker ecosystem while collaborating with other CUs  Example: Upcoming governance Fire Drill      Facilitator Credentials  Involvement in MakerDAO  Began accumulating MKR in 2017 Contributor to the Black Thursday Vault Compensation Plan (failed)  Recognized Delegate Compensation (passed)  MKR/DAI LP proposal (failed)   Experience Prior to MakerDAO  Former primary maintainer of open source scientific software OpenMx  Author of various statistical software for R: ifaTools, pcFactorStan  Intense hobbyist interest in business design, nutrition science, mental health  2016-2021 Postdoctoral Fellow, Virginia Commonwealth University Ph.D. Quantitative Psychology, 2016 (University of Virginia) 2009–2011 Software Engineer, Palo Alto Software, Eugene, OR 1996–2001 Software Engineer, NatWest/Deutsche Bank, New York City, NY 1993–1995 Software Engineer, Various Companies, New York City, NY  Lots of contributions to free and open source software   Related Documents   @travinimmunefi’s Facilitator MIP  Core Unit Mandate MIP Core Unit Budget MIP Core Unit MKR Budget MIP

content.content: I’m going to be quite blunt here. I’m hoping to avoid any more drama than necessary. I’m not going to discuss or debate this position beyond this post in public or in private. Feel free to take it or leave it. I do not believe that Joshua should be a Facilitator within MakerDAO. Having interacted with him multiple times over the last few years, I do not trust his judgement, and have seen no signs of improvement over that time. Personally, I would not put him in a position of responsibility over anything I cared about. (Views my own, and not reflective of GovAlpha, obviously.)

content.content: LongForWisdom:  I’m going to be quite blunt here. I’m hoping to avoid any more drama than necessary. I’m not going to discuss or debate this position beyond this post in public or in private. Feel free to take it or leave it.   This is ad hominem that isn’t useful to my decision-making. I’d find it quite helpful if you could provide more background info on how you came to this conclusion.

content.content: I have a lot of admiration for LFW. He has been a steady light that has guided the community, me included, to engage with the DAO in a respectful and constructive way. I might even say that I have felt more free to play and be informal because I knew that LFW had my back, that he was the adult in the room.     ChrisBlec:  This is ad hominem that isn’t useful to my decision-making.   You beat me to it Chris. LFW and I had a chat on Discord back in April where he expressed some of his concerns to me privately. I agreed when he pointed out some specific mistakes that I have made. I invite LFW to detail the relevant concerns here. I know that my behavior hasn’t been perfect, but I think I can promise to face my defects in a drama-minimized way. Let the voters be informed.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Its useful insomuch as you trust LongForWisdom’s judgement. Might not be very useful for a new delegate, but can be very useful for long term members who know him. It’s also not an ad hominem. An ad hominem is an attack on a person to discredit his argument. This is an attack on a person to discredit the person.

content.content: Can @TravinImmunefi share more about your thought on @psychonaut 's proposal?
Honestly, it shouldn’t be useful to anyone in an environment of rational discourse. Let’s stick to facts. It would be super-helpful if @LongForWisdom could share the reasons for his characterization.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: ChrisBlec:  Let’s stick to facts. It would be super-helpful if @LongForWisdom could share the reasons for his characterization.   Aight, fine. In multiple instances he’s made decisions and jumped to actions that are either sub-optimal or harmful in a minor way (I believe minor because he’s not had a great deal of responsibility thus far). Some of these have just been baffling, others irritating, and some infuriating. Most recently:   Announcing to delegates that we would be having emergency drills - normally you’d only get to do an emergency drill with zero prior knowledge once, we didn’t get to do that. This also led to multiple delegates believing that an actual minor emergency was a drill.   Publicly posting incorrect delegate response times on the aforementioned minor emergency after I asked him to get me a list of the actual on-chain vote times - something that could have been avoided if he’d just done what I’d asked him to, or had checked with me before posting incorrect information.   Leaking sensitive information on aforementioned minor emergency in the same post - again something that could have been avoided by either doing what I’d actually asked him to do, or checking with me before posting.   Asking for GovAlpha to review a proposal that I believe was meant to bring better nutrition to the DAO - I don’t think was ever posted, and I have trouble remembering the contents because I noped out of it almost immediately when I read the part about running a questionnaire including questions of an extremely personal nature. I bring this up because it baffled me why he’d written it and how it had anything to do with Immunefi, it also baffled me that he thought anyone in crypto-culture would want to fill in a questionnaire about their dietary habits, it further baffled me that he thought it would be something appropriate for GovAlpha to spend time reviewing.   Submitting the Recognized Delegate Compensation MIP without confirming that GovAlpha was happy with it. To be clear, he was under no obligation to do this, but we’d been working on it fairly actively and not being consulted was frustrating.   Posting (since deleted) an extremely half-assed version of a Intangible Asset Request for Immunefi to take ownership of a MakerDAO security repo. Not only was it not a valid on posting, but he’d also neglected to speak to PE, the owners of the repo about transferring it before posting it. When questioned, I asked if he’d done that because he felt the whole process was a waste of time and an example of governance bureaucracy, and he confirmed that yes, that was the reason. If he’d followed the process as written he would have spoken to PE initially and learned that they weren’t comfortable transferring ownership.   In summary (and as pointed out initially), at this point I don’t trust his judgement or decision-making. I’m sure lots of you are more charitable, but I genuinely worry that Joshua will do meaningful damage to the DAO at some point in this role.     CodeKnight:  It’s also not an ad hominem. An ad hominem is an attack on a person to discredit his argument. This is an attack on a person to discredit the person.   Quick note on this, I didn’t and don’t want this to be seen as an attack on Joshua, that why I was initially very succinct. You’re more or less correct though, the argument Joshua is making is that’s he should be onboarded as a facilitator - the argument is the person in this case.     LongForWisdom:  I’m not going to discuss or debate this position beyond this post in public or in private.   Want to just point out that I’m not going to spend time sourcing these or attempting to prove any of this beyond reasonable doubt. My sense of personal responsibility was satisfied by my first post. This is already way more detail than I wanted to provide, and I’ve only done so due to a combination of Joshua saying he’s fine with it, and because of @ChrisBlec repeatedly @'ing me despite my making it very clear I didn’t intend to discuss it further.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Thank you for providing these details. I’m a big believer in transparency. I just want to add a few mitigating points that are hopefully drama-minimized and will not require a further back-and-forth.      LongForWisdom:   Publicly posting incorrect delegate response times on the aforementioned minor emergency after I asked him to get me a list of the actual on-chain vote times - something that could have been avoided if he’d just done what I’d asked him to, or had checked with me before posting incorrect information. Leaking sensitive information on aforementioned minor emergency in the same post - again something that could have been avoided by either doing what I’d actually asked him to do, or checking with me before posting.    Nothing I posted was not already public information. I had no non-public knowledge of the incident and continue to know nothing that is not already public information.     LongForWisdom:   Submitting the Recognized Delegate Compensation MIP without confirming that GovAlpha was happy with it. To be clear, he was under no obligation to do this, but we’d been working on it fairly actively and not being consulted was frustrating.    This happened after the PR from GovAlpha was merged. I did not learn that LFW regarded my action as a process violation until April. I do not have further comments on the allegations and accept responsibility.

content.content: This proposal is currently being voted on. Its RP will run from 06/13 to 06/27. Please vote here.

LongForWisdom:  It was frustrating because we’d previously been actively working on it with you, and didn’t get a heads up that you’d decided to submit it.   So you saying that, the step of I hereby formally submit to the governance cycle is a non-negotiable, irrevocable step? I know it’s water under the bridge, but I would have agreed to another month of delay. However, I did feel like the compensation trial and trial extension cast a shadow of doubt on delegate compensation. Why not formally vote on it? Refinements can always be proposed by subsequent amendments.

content.content: Doo_StableLab:  Can @TravinImmunefi share more about your thought on @psychonaut 's proposal?   Hello, I apologize for my late reply here. I was the one who encouraged the application of @psychonaut in order for him to be better able to represent IS-001 during calls given my restrictive schedule. Under the description of the Deputy Facilitator role mentioned in MIP39c2-SP24: Adding Immunefi Security Core Unit - IS-001, the details of the role can be found here. One of the key aspects of the role 3-6 months in, which has already passed, is to: “Act as a representative of the CU to the Maker community in community channels and engage in external cryptocurrency channels as substitute for the Facilitator when needed” Feedback was provided that Joshua substituting for me on the Mandated Actors calls so much was not appropriate, but unfortunately with changes to my personal family life, the time of the call, especially with how it is now with daylight savings, is not something I can comfortably do, though I pushed to join the calls over the past months after it was called out, aside from a few emergency cases and times I was OOO (like next week). I am also not a significant member on that call and thus I did not feel it to be right to request a time change and thus making everyone move their schedule. This issue prompted the suggestion of Joshua becoming a Facilitator as he is unable to perform all the duties necessary of the role I described unless he gets the Facilitator role. Joshua has already attended about half of the MA calls (it’s why it got pointed out as a problem) and has been diligent in taking notes and communicating things to me. I understand that LongForWisdom doesn’t wish to discuss further the points he brought up, and I’ll respect that. Instead, I’ll endorse Joshua for the good work that he has done. The launch and the subsequent operation of IS-001 was not exactly as smooth as we had hoped. There were (and are) changes at Immunefi that made things a bit more difficult for us to deliver. As the first and only client of Immunefi that has any of these services, we were entering some level of experimentation, though granted we had hoped to leverage these in potential future services for other clients. That has not materialized, though that’s outside of the scope of this. Joshua throughout this time has been proactive in figuring out ways to help as well as get his “hands dirty” and do the work necessary. For example, we’re in the process of restructuring our triaging process for the bug bounty program, and Joshua has stepped up to provide the necessary triaging assistance on call especially while I’m away. He’s always been communicative with me and I have had no issues with his communication, as well as took a proactive stance whenever he felt I was late on things or found things that would make things more secure. I’ve also significantly underestimated the amount of work I needed to do as a Facilitator, both in the frontloading and in the maintenance of the core unit, and Joshua being around and helping, as well as proactively figuring out what he could take from me, and thus do better since I was extremely overloaded, even with last-minute requests, was really a life-saver. I will clarify though with regards to the statement about leaking sensitive information since this is something significant especially for IS-001. From our side, what was considered sensitive was not what was posted by Joshua and it’s not what I or Immunefi requested to keep confidential temporarily. I understand that at the time there was some confusion about what was asked to be kept confidential, but I want to clarify that what Joshua posted did not fall under it. There were some minor mistakes that Joshua made, but he worked with me to make it right. He’s also very transparent about them and we had them listed on our monthly updates. Had these been major mistakes, I would have withheld this recommendation, but they are not.
